Articular ends (takes part in the transmission of weight)

Example: Head of the femur

Nonarticular (does not take part in the transmission of weight)

Provides attachment to one or more tend that exert traction on the epiphysis.

Example: Tubercles of humerus, mastoid process.

Phylogenetically an independent bone, which in humans is fused to another bone.

It is not always present

Traction epiphysis

Aberrant epiphysis

questions.text: An experiment is performed in the laboratory to study the movement of ions across the membranes. options.text: K + ions will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [K + ] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

options.label: B
options.text: K + ions will diffuse from solution B to solution A until the [K + ] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

options.label: C
options.text: KCl will diffuse from solution A to solution B until the [KCl] of both solutions is 50.5 mM

options.label: D
options.text: K + will diffuse from solution A to solution B until a membrane potential develops with solution A negative with respect to solution B

questions.correct_answer: D. K + will diffuse from solution A to solution B until a membrane potential develops with solution A negative with respect to solution B

questions.text: Damage to the medial collateral ligament by a valgus force often causes concomitant damage to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Ligaments/Structures

                          Mechanism of injury

Medial meniscus

Damage to the medial collateral ligament by a valgus force often causes concomitant damage to the medial meniscus because of this relationship.

Anterior cruciate ligament

Anterior cruciate ligament is torn when an athlete is cutting, deceleration, jumping, or landing, which pushes the knee into a position with enough force that causes the ACL to rupture.

Lateral meniscus

Lateral meniscus is injured by force medial to the knee joint.

Posterior cruciate ligament

Posterior cruciate ligament is torn by a direct blow to the anterior aspect of the proximal tibia on a flexed knee when the ankle is in plantar flexion.

Fixative Purpose Commonly Used in Advantages Disadvantages
Formalin Routine histological processing Light microscopy Widely available and economical Can cause tissue shrinkage and distortion
Glutaraldehyde Electron microscopy Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) Preserves cellular ultrastructure Toxic, requires careful handling and disposal
Paraformaldehyde Better preservation of antigenicity Immunofluorescence, immunohistochemistry Preserves antigen structures Slower fixation and penetration
Methanol Preservation of RNA and some antigens Fluorescence microscopy Compatible with RNA and certain antibodies May cause significant sample shrinkage
Acetone Quick fixation for enzyme localization Enzyme localization studies Fast fixation and dehydration Poor preservation of lipids and some antigens

questions.text: The trial of Mr. Gupta is in court now. After having thoroughly studied the case, the judge declared that a magistrate inquest was not needed in this case. What among the following could be the offence Mr. Gupta is being charged for?
questions.explanation:
Sr. No. Feature Magistrate inquest Police inquest
1. Investigating officer An inquest conducted by DM, SDM or Magistrate who is qualified and experienced Conducted by a police officer who is not qualified in law or medicine
2. Informing Magistrate Need not inform anyone Needs to inform the Magistrate of the area
3. Types of cases handled Can hold inquest in all cases of suspicious deaths Cannot hold an inquest in cases of death in custody, jail, police firing or dowry deaths
4. Witnesses Police help the Magistrate. Does not require the signature of the witnesses Panchas help, who are chosen at random to sign the report
5. Value of statements made by a witness No value, not admissible in court Valuable and admissible in court
6. Warrant for arrest Can issue an arrest warrant of the accused Cannot issue a warrant, but can arrest an accused in cognizable offence
7. Exhumation Can order a body to be exhumed Cannot order
8. Autopsy Does not send dead bodies for autopsy indiscriminately Sends dead bodies for autopsy indiscriminately
9. Analysis of viscera Can order chemical analysis of viscera Cannot order
10. Quality of investigation Superior to police inquest Inferior to Magistrate inquest

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents to the ophthalmologist complaining of severe headache, blurred vision, and redness in both eyes for 5 days. The patient is also hypertensive for 15 years. On examination, there is tenderness around the eyes and the intraocular pressure is raised . The doctor decides to prescribe a topical drug to the patient. Which of the following drugs could be given?
questions.explanation:
Drug Class Example Drugs Mechanism of Action
Prostaglandin Analogues Latanoprost, Bimatoprost Increase the outflow of aqueous humor (fluid in the eye) by relaxing the muscles in the eye's drainage system (trabecular meshwork).
Beta-Blockers Timolol, Betaxolol Reduce the production of aqueous humor by blocking the beta receptors that regulate its production.
Alpha Agonists Brimonidine, Apraclonidine Decrease aqueous humor production and increase its outflow, also reducing the amount of fluid produced in the eye.
Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors Dorzolamide, Brinzolamide Reduce the production of aqueous humor by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase, an enzyme involved in fluid secretion.
Rho Kinase Inhibitors Netarsudil Enhance outflow of aqueous humor by relaxing the trabecular meshwork and increasing fluid drainage.
Cholinergic Agonists Pilocarpine, Carbachol Increase outflow of aqueous humor and constrict the pupil by stimulating cholinergic receptors in the eye.
Combination Eye Drops Dorzolamide/Timolol, Latanoprost/Timolol Combine different classes of medications to target both aqueous humor production and outflow.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented to the eye clinic complaining of pain in the eye associated with decreased vision . Examination of the patient’s medical history revealed that he was operated for cataracts in his left eye and also done pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) for cataracts and proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR) in his left eye. The patient with a history of type 2 DM for the last 15 years. On examination of the patient eye, he has diabetic macular oedema with glaucoma . Which of the following drug should be contraindicated for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Drug Class Mechanism of Action Examples Common Side Effects Contraindications
Prostaglandin analogs Increase uveoscleral outflow, reduce intraocular pressure Latanoprost, Bimatoprost Eye irritation, hyperpigmentation of the iris and eyelashes, eyelash growth,Macular Oedema Hypersensitivity to the drug, active intraocular inflammation, aphakia (absence of the lens)
Beta-blockers Reduce aqueous humor production Timolol, Betaxolol Eye irritation, systemic effects (e.g., bradycardia, bronchospasm) Asthma, severe bradycardia, heart block, history of bronchospasm or obstructive pulmonary disease
Alpha-2 adrenergic agonists Reduce aqueous humor production, increase uveoscleral outflow Brimonidine, Apraclonidine Ocular allergy, dry mouth, fatigue, systemic hypotension Severe cardiovascular disease, use with MAO inhibitors, hypersensitivity to the drug
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors Reduce aqueous humor production Dorzolamide, Brinzolamide Ocular stinging, bitter taste, systemic effects (e.g., metabolic acidosis, electrolyte imbalance) Sulfa allergy, hepatic impairment, severe renal impairment
Cholinergic agonists Increase outflow through the trabecular meshwork, constrict pupil Pilocarpine, Carbachol Ocular irritation, blurred vision, headache, systemic effects (e.g., sweating, gastrointestinal disturbances) History of retinal detachment, asthma, iritis, use with caution in patients with cardiovascular disease or urinary tract obstruction

questions.text: A child born with multiple congenital defect including cleft palate, neural tube defect, atrial, septal defect and microcephaly which of the following drug is used by mother during pregnancy?
questions.explanation:
Pregnancy Category Description
A No risk in controlled human studies:Adequate and well-controlled human studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in the first trimester of pregnancy (and there is no evidence of risk in later trimesters).
B No risk in other studies:Animal reproduction studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women OR Animal studies have shown an adverse effect, but adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in any trimester.
C Risk not ruled out:Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.
D Positive evidence of risk:There is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience or studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.
X Contraindicated in pregnancy:Studies in animals or humans have demonstrated fetal abnormalities and/or there is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience, and the risks involved in use of the drug in pregnant women clearly outweigh potential benefits.
N FDA has not yet classified the drug into a specified pregnancy category.

questions.text: A 25-year-old boy comes to the physician with a complaint of fever, decreased hearing, and painless foul-smelling discharge from his left ear. The patient was treated with antibiotics before but did not respond to antibiotic therapy. On physical examination, there is an enlargement of preauricular lymph nodes. From the otoscopic examination, the patient has shown multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane. A biopsy was done, showing pale granulation tissue. According to the given information, which of the following statements is correct about the given condition? Multiple perforations in tympanic membrane Pale granulation tissue is seen No extra auricular complications Painless condition Corticosteroids - The mainstay of treatment
questions.explanation:
Definition Tubercular infection of the middle ear
Causative Agent Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Transmission Usually via inhalation of respiratory droplets from an active TB patient, rarely through direct spread from a nearby TB focus
Symptoms - Persistent ear discharge
  - Hearing loss
  - Ear pain
  - Tinnitus (ringing in the ears)
  - Dizziness
  - Facial muscle weakness (if adjacent nerve affected)
Diagnosis - Thorough medical history and physical examination
  - Tuberculin skin test (PPD test) or TB blood test
  - Imaging studies (CT scan, MRI)
  - Middle ear fluid analysis (culture and PCR)
Treatment - Antitubercular therapy (ATT) for several months
  - Surgical intervention for severe cases or complications
Prognosis Generally good with appropriate and timely treatment, but complications can lead to hearing impairment
Prevention - Early diagnosis and treatment of TB in other parts of the body
  - Isolation of active TB patients to prevent spread
  - Infection control measures in healthcare settings

questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Asherman's syndrome, also known as intrauterine adhesions or uterine synechiae, is a condition characterized by the presence of scar tissue (adhesions) within the uterine cavity.
Etiology Commonly caused by trauma to the uterine lining, often due to previous uterine surgeries, such as dilation and curettage (D&C) following a miscarriage, therapeutic abortion, or postpartum curettage. Other causes may include uterine infections, endometritis, or other conditions leading to uterine trauma.
Clinical Presentation - Absence of menstrual periods (amenorrhea) or light, infrequent periods (oligomenorrhea).
  - Infertility or recurrent pregnancy losses.
  - Pelvic pain or discomfort.
Diagnosis - History of previous uterine surgery or trauma.
  - Transvaginal ultrasound may reveal a characteristic appearance of the uterus with thin or absent endometrial lining and the presence of adhesions.
  - Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing Asherman's syndrome, allowing direct visualization of the uterine cavity and the extent of adhesions.
Management - Hysteroscopic surgery: Adhesiolysis (removal of adhesions) under hysteroscopic guidance to restore the normal uterine cavity.
  - Hormonal therapy: After adhesiolysis, hormonal therapy with estrogen and progesterone may be prescribed to promote endometrial regrowth and prevent recurrence of adhesions.
  - In severe cases, repeat hysteroscopic surgeries or adjunctive treatments like intrauterine balloon placement may be necessary to maintain uterine cavity integrity.
Prognosis The prognosis varies depending on the extent and severity of the adhesions. With appropriate treatment, many women can achieve normal menstrual cycles and fertility. However, some cases may be challenging to treat, and recurrence of adhesions is possible.

questions.explanation:
Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea
Pathophysiology
  • Aden tonsillar hypertrophy
Clinical manifestations
  • Night symptoms
    • Loud snoring, pauses in breathing, gasping
    • Enuresis parasomnias (e.g. Sleepwalking, sleep terrors)
  • Day symptoms
    • Inappropriate naps or falling asleep during school
    • Irritability, inattention, learning problems, behavioral problem
    • Mouth breathing, nasal speech
Complications
  • Poor growth (i.e. failure to thrive)
  • Poor school performance
  • Cardiopulmonary (e.g., hypertension, structural heart changes)
Management
  • Tonsillectomy & adenoidectomy

questions.text: A 70 year old male who has been chewing tobacco for the past 50 years present with a six months history of large, fungating, soft papillary lesions in the oral cavity. The lesion has penetrated into the mandible. Lymph nodes are not palpable. Two biopsies taken from the lesion proper show be­nign appearing papillomatosis with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis infiltrating the subjacent tissues. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective:
  • ➤ BUCCAL CARCINOMA
  • ➤ BUCCAL CARCINOMA
  • ➤ Site of origin. Most common site is the angle of mouth or the line of occlusion of upper and lower teeth. It may also arise from the buccal sulcus where “pan” or tobacco quid is kept. As the whole of buccal mucosa is “condemned,” carcinoma may be multicentric. Gross appearance. Lesion may be exophytic or ulceroinfiltrative; the latter may infiltrate deeply. Exophytic type may be associated with erythroleukoplakia. Buccal mucosa is also the most common site for verrucous carcinoma which is a white papillary growth with considerable keratinization. Local spread. From its site of origin, the lesion may spread deeply involving submucosa → muscle → subcutaneous fat → skin. Involvement of buccinator muscle or anterior masseter causes trismus. Tumour may spread radially from its site of origin and involve angle of the mouth and lip anteriorly, retromolar trigone and medial pterygoid posteriorly, upper gingivobuccal sulcus and maxilla superiorly, lower gingivobuccal sulcus and alveolar ridge and gums inferiorly. Lymphatic spread. Nodal involvement occurs in about 50% of cases. Submandibular and later the upper jugular nodes may get involved. Upper jugular nodes may also be involved, directly skipping the submandibular group. Clinical features. Early lesions are asymptomatic. Pain and bleeding are seen when lesions are ulcerative and invade deeply. Involvement of the buccinator, masseter or the pterygoid muscles causes trismus. Fungating mass over the cheek, or a foul-smelling bleeding mass in the oral cavity are late feature
  • ➤ Site of origin. Most common site is the angle of mouth or the line of occlusion of upper and lower teeth. It may also arise from the buccal sulcus where “pan” or tobacco quid is kept. As the whole of buccal mucosa is “condemned,” carcinoma may be multicentric.
  • ➤ Gross appearance. Lesion may be exophytic or ulceroinfiltrative; the latter may infiltrate deeply. Exophytic type may be associated with erythroleukoplakia.
  • ➤ Buccal mucosa is also the most common site for verrucous carcinoma which is a white papillary growth with considerable keratinization. Local spread. From its site of origin, the lesion may spread deeply involving submucosa → muscle → subcutaneous fat → skin. Involvement of buccinator muscle or anterior masseter causes trismus. Tumour may spread radially from its site of origin and involve angle of the mouth and lip anteriorly, retromolar trigone and medial pterygoid posteriorly, upper gingivobuccal sulcus and maxilla superiorly, lower gingivobuccal sulcus and alveolar ridge and gums inferiorly.
  • ➤ Lymphatic spread. Nodal involvement occurs in about 50% of cases. Submandibular and later the upper jugular nodes may get involved. Upper jugular nodes may also be involved, directly skipping the submandibular group.
  • ➤ Clinical features. Early lesions are asymptomatic. Pain and bleeding are seen when lesions are ulcerative and invade deeply. Involvement of the buccinator, masseter or the pterygoid muscles causes trismus. Fungating mass over the cheek, or a foul-smelling bleeding mass in the oral cavity are late feature

Five years later, in the follow-up of the breast reconstruction, the patient presented with right-sided recurrent breast swelling for the past 8 months . She is sent to the radiological department for further evaluation for breast imaging. Which of the fo llowing is the preferred investigation in this case?

A cataract is an opacity in the transparent lens that leads to blurry vision. The most common type is the senile cataract. A senile cataract passes through different stages of maturation. What is the most common complication of the cataract stage shown in the given image?

A female newborn presents with a square shaped skull with a short occipital–frontal diameter. Premature closure of which of the following sutures is the most likely cause of this finding?

25 year old Aidan was going to a party. The time was already midnight. He didn’t put the seat belt on while driving. His car involved in a road traffic accident came to the emergency department. On arrival in the emergency department, the patient is noted to have stridor, with marked respiratory distress, and an oxygen saturation of 88% despite 100% oxygen by mask. He has extensive facial injuries, a flail chest, and poor chest expansion. Bag-mask-valve ventilation is ineffective. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

The national plan of action of the Government of India focuses on under-served areas with an emphasis on community participation. It facilitates the formation of state-level Vision 2020- plans of action and programmes led by the state governments, along with intensive input from local and international NGOs. According to the Indian version of Vision 2020, which of the following diseases is not included ?

A woman, gravid 0, para 0,underwent infertility evaluation. The infertility was diagnosed as being secondary to an ovulation because of polycystic ovary syndrome. Which of the following statements is most likely to be true?

options.label: A
options.text: She has a low body mass index

options.label: C
options.text: Androgen production is primarily from adrenals

questions.text: Madison is a 4-year-old girl living in Tennessee. She is daughter of Rebecca who works as a fitness instructor at a New Orleans Gym. She had left her job ever since she gave birth to Madison. She usually takes good care of Madison at home and is not ready to hire anyone to babysit her. Recently She noticed that Madison had been scratching her head a lot. She also is losing considerable amount of her Hair every time she combs. She is concerned that her daughter is balding. She immediately brings this to the attention of her family paediatrician. The Doctor measured her vital which given below : temperature is 101°F (37.6°C), blood pressure is 130/70 mmHg, pulse is 99/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination showed that the child's scalps as in image A. The Doctor did a Wood's UV lamp examination which caused the hair to fluorescence bright green. which confirm the diagnosis. What is the most likely etiological agent?

A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department for severe pain and swelling in her lower extremity . He stated the pain scale to be 9/10 and it happened in a short duration. The patient has a past medical history of obesity, diabetes, and seizures disorder . He is currently on metformin, insulin, and valproic acid. The patient is a IV drug abuser and alcoholic. His vitals are BP-140/90,PR- 98, RR-18. On physical exam you note anasarca and asymmetric lower extremity swelling. Lab investigations and ultasound was done .Based on the ultrasound finding the patient was started on Heparin. Urinalysis showed a fatty cast . Laboratory studies are shown below. Na+: 139 mEq/L, K+: 5.7 mEq/L, HCO3-: 23 mEq/L, Urea nitrogen: 20mg/dL , Ca2+: 5.5 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL ,random Glucose: 70 mg/dL what do you think be the most likely diagnosis?

Arilla was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis 2 years ago when she was 13 years old. She was managed with steroid therapy. Now she presents to the emergency department with a 36 hour history of nausea, severe bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain. On examination she is febrile and pale . She has a blood pressure of 90/60 mmhg and a heart rate of 128 bpm. On examination her abdomen is distended and diffusely tender. Leukocytosis is demonstrated in a CBC with a left shift. The patient receives IV fluid resuscitation and nasogastric tube decompression. Which of the following could be the choice for further therapeutic intervention?

options.label: E
options.text: high-dose IV steroids and broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.correct_answer: E. high-dose IV steroids and broad-spectrum antibiotics

questions.text: A primigravida presents at term pregnancy in labour. On examination she has good uterine contractions and fetal heart. Vaginal examination reveals a cervical dilatation of 4 cm, fetal head at +1 station and a clinically adequate pelvis. The most likely position of the fetal head in this case is?

Margot was cleaning her toilet. She didn’t notice that her 5 year old child was playing with the drain cleaner liquid. Her child spilled the liquid to his hands . His hands were injured and he started crying. Margot immediately took him to the nearby clinic in her car. It took her 15 minutes to reach there. On arrival at the clinic, the boy was holding his right hand in the flexed position. His temperature was normal. He had a blood pressure of105/70. His heart rate was 100 bpm. He was not able to flex or extend his hands completely. Palpable radial pulses were present. On examination he had a 4x4 area of reddened blistered skin. It was very tender to light touch. Capillary refill time is less than 3 seconds. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in the management?

A 40 year old male was brought to the emergency bay after a motor vehicle accident. The prior incident; when he was hanging out with his friends in his garden, he was stung by a bee. Knowing that he is allergic to bee sting, he was rushed to the hospital for treatment. On the way, he met with an accident and landed on his spine and lost a lot of blood. Upon arrival he vitals were, BP- 90/70 mmHg; RR- 12 bpm; HR- 125 bpm; TEMP- 35 C. This patient is in which type of shock ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective
  • ➤ Distributive shock describes the pattern of cardiovascular responses characterizing a variety of conditions, including septic shock, anaphylaxis and spinal cord injury. Inadequate organ perfusion is accompanied by vascular dilatation with hypotension, low systemic vascular resistance , inadequate afterload and a resulting abnormally high cardiac output.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents to his physician with the complaint of loss of peripheral vision. Which of the following findings are demonstrated by the subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan, shown here?
Which of the following can deliver 100% oxygen?

An 35 year old male illegal immigrant from tropical regions of South East Asia residing near the sea, was brought to the emergency bay for fever and upper abdominal discomfort associated with malaise and anorexia. He complains of generalized itching. He also exhibited signs of biliary colic and jaundice. Stool examination revealed eggs of the Clonorchis sinensis. What is the ideal drug of choice in this patient ?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning objective
  • ➤ Praziquantel and albendazole are the drugs of choice for treating Asiatic Cholangiohepatitis.

questions.text: A 32 year old , G3A2, presents with 32 weeks of pregnancy and labour pains. She has a history of previous 2 miscarriages in the 4th and 5th months of pregnancy. On examination, uterine contractions are present and cervix is 2 cm dilated. Management of this patient includes all of the following, EXCEPT?

Ben is a 7 year old is a preschool kid, studying at Parma Preschool, Ohio. His mother Jenny, working as a beautician at Clintonville Beauty Salon. A week ago, Jenny notices a diffuse itchy rash over Ben's abdomen, back and upper legs. He had no there associated symptoms and was well and had no sick contacts. She decided to visit the doctor at the weekend. At the doctors office, a physician examination was performed. he was afebrile and cooperative. A skin examination was done. The examination revealed single large, well-circumscribed pink plaque over his mid-abdomen, and many pink papules of varying sizes over his abdomen, back, and thighs as shown in the image. The doctor suggested observation and follow up for a month. On his next visit to the clinic, the rash resolved itself without any intervention. What would be the most probable diagnosis?

A woman has her pregnancy suddenly terminated due to intrauterine fetal death. At autopsy, the fetus shows severe pallor, generalized edema, and hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following would you suspe.

While on Emergency duty, a psychiatry resident is called to assess a 15 month old child in pediatric ward who has developed a muscle spasm in his neck causing him to have a twisted neck, and difficulty in opening mouth since last 1 hour. The child was admitted 4 days back in view of an abdominal infection for which he had been receiving appropriate treatment and care. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause for the patient’s symptoms?
